title: B. Sets and Union
description: You have n n sets of integers S 1 , S 2 , … , S n S 1 , S 2 , … , S n . We call a set S S attainable , if it is possible to choose some (possibly, none) of the sets S 1 , S 2 , … , S n S 1 , S 2 , … , S n so that S S is equal to their union † † . If you choose none of S 1 , S 2 , … , S n S 1 , S 2 , … , S n , their union is an empty set. Find the maximum number of elements in an attainable S S such that S ≠ S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ … ∪ S n S ≠ S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ … ∪ S n . † † The union of sets A 1 , A 2 , … , A k A 1 , A 2 , … , A k is defined as the set of elements present in at least one of these sets. It is denoted by A 1 ∪ A 2 ∪ … ∪ A k A 1 ∪ A 2 ∪ … ∪ A k . For example, { 2 , 4 , 6 } ∪ { 2 , 3 } ∪ { 3 , 6 , 7 } = { 2 , 3 , 4 , 6 , 7 } { 2 , 4 , 6 } ∪ { 2 , 3 } ∪ { 3 , 6 , 7 } = { 2 , 3 , 4 , 6 , 7 } .
input: Input Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t t ( 1 ≤ t ≤ 100 1 ≤ t ≤ 100 ). The description of the test cases follows. The first line of each test case contains a single integer n n ( 1 ≤ n ≤ 50 1 ≤ n ≤ 50 ). The following n n lines describe the sets S 1 , S 2 , … , S n S 1 , S 2 , … , S n . The i i -th of these lines contains an integer k i k i ( 1 ≤ k i ≤ 50 1 ≤ k i ≤ 50 ) — the number of elements in S i S i , followed by k i k i integers s i , 1 , s i , 2 , … , s i , k i s i , 1 , s i , 2 , … , s i , k i ( 1 ≤ s i , 1 < s i , 2 < … < s i , k i ≤ 50 1 ≤ s i , 1 < s i , 2 < … < s i , k i ≤ 50 ) — the elements of S i S i .
output: Output For each test case, print a single integer — the maximum number of elements in an attainable S S such that S ≠ S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ … ∪ S n S ≠ S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ … ∪ S n .
note: Note In the first test case, S = S 1 ∪ S 3 = { 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 } S = S 1 ∪ S 3 = { 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 } is the largest attainable set not equal to S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ S 3 = { 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 } S 1 ∪ S 2 ∪ S 3 = { 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 } . In the second test case, we can pick S = S 2 ∪ S 3 ∪ S 4 = { 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 } S = S 2 ∪ S 3 ∪ S 4 = { 2 , 3 , 4 , 5 , 6 } . In the third test case, we can pick S = S 2 ∪ S 5 = S 2 ∪ S 3 ∪ S 5 = { 3 , 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 , 10 } S = S 2 ∪ S 5 = S 2 ∪ S 3 ∪ S 5 = { 3 , 5 , 6 , 8 , 9 , 10 } . In the fourth test case, the only attainable set is S = ∅ .
